category.text: $module$/top/Default for 7.4 The Inverse of a Matrix

info.text: The default category for questions shared in context '7.4 The Inverse of a Matrix'.

name.text: 7.4.1 The inverse of a square matrix (copy)

questiontext.text:
The inverse of a square matrix

We know that any non-zero number \(k\) has an inverse; for example \(2\) has an inverse \(\frac{1}{2}\) or \(2^{-1}\). The inverse of the number \(k\) is usually written \(\frac{1}{k}\) or, more formally, by \(k^{-1}\). This numerical inverse has the property that 

\( k\times k^{-1}=k^{-1}\times k=1\)

We now show that an inverse of a matrix can, in certain circumstances, also be defined. 

Given an \(n\times n\) square matrix \(A,\) then an \(n\times n\) square matrix \(B\) is said to be the inverse matrix of \(A\) if

\(AB=BA=I\)

where \(I\) is, as usual, the identity matrix (or unit matrix) of the appropriate size.


Example 6

6 Show that the inverse matrix of \(A=\left[\begin{array}{cc}-1&1\\ -2&0\end{array}\right]\) is \(B=\left[\begin{array}{cc}0&-\frac{1}{2}\\ 1&-\frac{1}{2}\end{array}\right]\)

Solution

All we need to do is check that \(AB=BA=I\). 

\(AB=\left[\begin{array}{cc}-1&1\\ -2&0\end{array}\right]\times\frac{1}{2}\left[\begin{array}{cc}0&-1\\ 2&-1\end{array}\right] = \frac{1}{2}\left[\begin{array}{cc}-1&1\\ -2&0\end{array}\right]\times\left[\begin{array}{cc}0&-1\\ 2&-1\end{array}\right] = \frac{1}{2}\left[\begin{array}{cc}2&0\\ 0&2\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{cc}1&0\\ 0&1\end{array}\right] \)

We make three important remarks: 

\(\bullet\)Non-square matrices do not have inverses. 

\(\bullet\)The inverse of \(A\) is usually written \(A^{-1}\). 

\(\bullet\)Not all square matrices have inverses.


\(\bullet\)If a matrix has an inverse then that inverse is unique.

  Suppose \(B\) and \(C\) are both inverses of \(A\). Then, by definition of the inverse, 

  \(\qquad AB=BA=I\) and \(AC=CA=I\)

  Consider the two ways of forming the product \(CAB\)

  1. \(CAB=C(AB)=CI=C\)

  2. \(CAB=(CA)B=IB=B.\)

  Hence \(B=C\) and the inverse is unique. 


\(\bullet\)There is no such operation as division in matrix algebra.

  We do not write \(\dfrac{B}{A}\) but rather 

  \(\qquad A^{-1}B\ \ \text{or}\ \ BA^{-1},\)

  depending on the order required.

\(\bullet\)Assuming that the square matrix \(A\) has an inverse \(A^{-1}\) then the solution of the system of equations \(A X=B\) is found by pre-multiplying both sides by \(A^{-1}\). 


\(AX\) = \(B\)
pre-multiplying by} \(A^{-1}\):     \(A^{-1}(AX)\) = \(A^{-1}B\),
using associativity:   \((A^{-1}A)X\) = \(A^{-1}B\),
using \(A^{-1}A = I\): \(IX\) = \(A^{-1}B\),
using property of \(I\): \(X\) = \(A^{-1}B\)     which is the solution we seek.

name.text: 7.4.1.1 The inverse of a square matrix

questiontext.text:
The inverse of a square matrix Den inverse av en kvadratisk matrise

We know that any non-zero number \(k\) has an inverse; for example \(2\) has an inverse \(\frac{1}{2}\) or \(2^{-1}\). The inverse of the number \(k\) is usually written \(\frac{1}{k}\) or, more formally, by \(k^{-1}\). This numerical inverse has the property that 
 Vi vet at ethvert tall som ikke er null, \(k\), har en invers; for eksempel har \(2\) en invers \(\frac{1}{2}\) eller \(2^{-1}\). Inversen av tallet \(k\) er vanligvis skrevet som \(\frac{1}{k}\) eller mer formelt som \(k^{-1}\). Denne numeriske inversen har egenskapen at

\( k\times k^{-1}=k^{-1}\times k=1\)

We now show that an inverse of a matrix can, in certain circumstances, also be defined. Vi viser nå at en invers av en matrise kan, under visse omstendigheter, også defineres.

Given an \(n\times n\) square matrix \(A,\) then an \(n\times n\) square matrix \(B\) is said to be the inverse matrix of \(A\) if Gitt en \(n \times n\) kvadratisk matrise \(A,\) så er en \(n \times n\) kvadratisk matrise \(B\) sagt å være inversmatrisen til \(A\) hvis

\(AB=BA=I\)

where \(I\) is, as usual, the identity matrix (or unit matrix) of the appropriate size. hvor \(I\) som vanlig er identitetsmatrisen (eller enhetsmatrisen) med passende størrelse.

Example
Eksempel

Show that the inverse matrix of \(A=\left[\begin{array}{cc}-1&1\\ -2&0\end{array}\right]\) is \(B=\left[\begin{array}{cc}0&-\frac{1}{2}\\ 1&-\frac{1}{2}\end{array}\right]\) Vis at den inverse matrisen til \(A=\left[\begin{array}{cc}-1&1\\ -2&0\end{array}\right]\) er \(B=\left[\begin{array}{cc}0&-\frac{1}{2}\\ 1&-\frac{1}{2}\end{array}\right]\)

Solution Løsning

All we need to do is check that \(AB=BA=I\). Alt vi trenger å gjøre er å sjekke at \(AB=BA=I\).

\(AB=\left[\begin{array}{cc}-1&1\\ -2&0\end{array}\right]\times\frac{1}{2}\left[\begin{array}{cc}0&-1\\ 2&-1\end{array}\right] = \frac{1}{2}\left[\begin{array}{cc}-1&1\\ -2&0\end{array}\right]\times\left[\begin{array}{cc}0&-1\\ 2&-1\end{array}\right] = \frac{1}{2}\left[\begin{array}{cc}2&0\\ 0&2\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{cc}1&0\\ 0&1\end{array}\right] \)

We make three important remarks: Vi gjør tre viktige merknader:

  • Non-square matrices do not have inverses.
  • The inverse of \(A\) is usually written \(A^{-1}\).
  • Not all square matrices have inverses.
  • Ikke-firkantet matriser har ikke inverser.
  • Den inverse av \(A\) er vanligvis skrevet som \(A^{-1}\).
  • Ikke alle firkantet matriser har inverser.

name.text: 7.4.1.3 The inverse of a square matrix

questiontext.text:
• A matrix that has no inverse is said to be a singular matrix. A matrix which has an inverse is said to be non-singular. En matrise som ikke har en invers kalles en singulær matrise. En matrise som har en invers kalles ikke-singulær.

  • If a matrix has an inverse then that inverse is unique. Hvis en matrise har en invers, så er denne inversen unik.

    Suppose \(B\) and \(C\) are both inverses of \(A\). Then, by definition of the inverse, Anta at \(B\) og \(C\) begge er inverser av \(A\). Da, ifølge definisjonen av inversen, er

    \(AB = BA = I\) â€ƒ and â€ƒ \(AC = CA = I\). \(AB = BA = I\) og \(AC = CA = I\).

    Consider the two ways of forming the product \(CAB\). Vurder de to måtene å danne produktet \(CAB\).

    1. \(CAB = C(AB) = CI = C\).
    2. \(CAB = (CA)B = IB = B\).

    Hence, \(B = C\) and the inverse is unique. Altså, \(B = C\) og den inversen er unik.

  • There is no such operation as division in matrix algebra. Det finnes ingen operasjon som heter divisjon i matrisearitmetikk.

    We do not write \(\dfrac{B}{A}\) but rather \(A^{-1}B\) or \(BA^{-1}\), depending on the order required. Vi skriver ikke \(\dfrac{B}{A}\) men heller \(A^{-1}B\) eller \(BA^{-1}\), avhengig av rekkefølgen som kreves.

  • Assuming that the square matrix \(A\) has an inverse \(A^{-1}\) then the solution of the systems of equations \(AX = B\) is found by pre-multiplying both sides by \(A^{-1}\). Forutsatt at den kvadratiske matrisen \(A\) har en invers \(A^{-1}\), så finnes løsningen på systemet med ligninger \(AX = B\) ved å multiplisere begge sider på forhånd med \(A^{-1}\).

  • \(AX\)\(=\)\(B\)

  • pre-multiplying by \(A^{-1}\): â€ƒ \(A^{-1}(AX)\) \(=\) \(A^{-1}B\), multipliserer på forhånd \(A^{-1}\): \(A^{-1}(AX)\) \(=\) \(A^{-1}B\),

  • using associativity: \((A^{-1}A)X\) \(=\) \(B\), ved bruk av assosiativitet: \((A^{-1}A)X\) \(=\) \(B\),

  • using \(A^{-1}A = \): \(IX\) \(=\) \(A^{-1}B\), ved bruk av \(A^{-1}A = \): \(IX\) \(=\) \(A^{-1}B\),

  • using property of \(I\): \(X\) \(=\) \(A^{-1}B\) â€ƒ which is the solution we seek. ved bruk av egenskapen \(I\): \(X\) \(=\) \(A^{-1}B\) , som er løsningen vi ser etter.

name.text: 7.4.2.2 Key point ─ The inverse of a 2 x 2 matrix

questiontext.text:
You will see that, had we chosen Du vil se at hvis vi hadde valgt

\[C = \frac{1}{ad - bc} \begin{bmatrix}d & -b \\ -c & a\end{bmatrix}\]

instead of \(B\), then both products \(AC\) and \(CA\) will be equal to \(I\). This requires \(ad - bc \neq 0\). Hence this matrix \(C\) is the inverse of \(A\). However, if \(ad - bc = 0\) then \(A\) has no inverse. I stedet for \(B\), vil begge produktene \(AC\) og \(CA\) være lik \(I\). Dette krever at \(ad-bc \neq 0\). Derfor vil matrisen \(C\) være inversen til \(A\). Men hvis \(ad-bc=0\), så har \(A\) ingen invers.

Note that for the matrix Merk at for matrisen

\[A = \begin{bmatrix}1 & 0 \\ 2 & 0\end{bmatrix},\]

which occurred in the last question, \(ad - bc = 1 \times 0 - 0 \times 2 = 0\), confirming as we found that \(A\) has no inverse. som skjedde i forrige spørsmål, \(ad - bc = 1 \times 0 - 0 \times 2 = 0\), bekrefter som vi fant ut at \(A\) ikke har noen invers.

Key Point
 Nøkkelpunkt

If \(ad-bc\neq 0\) then the \(2\times 2\) matrix \(A=\left[\begin{array}{cc}a&b\\ c&d\end{array}\right]\) has a (unique) inverse given by Hvis \(ad-bc\neq 0\) så har matrisen \(2\times 2\) \(A=\left[\begin{array}{cc}a&b\\ c&d\end{array}\right]\) en (unik) invers gitt ved

\[A^{-1}=\frac{1}{ad-bc}\left[\begin{array}{cc}d& -b\\ -c & a \end{array}\right]\]

Note that \(ad-bc=|A|\), the determinant of the matrix \(A\). Merk at \(ad-bc=|A|\), determinanten til matrisen \(A\).

In words: To find the inverse of a \(2\times 2\) matrix \(A\) we interchange the diagonal elements, change the sign of the other two elements, and then divide by the determinant of \(A\). For å finne inversen av en \(2\times 2\) matrise \(A\), bytter vi diagonal elementene, endrer fortegnet til de andre to elementene, og deretter deler med determinanten til \(A\).

name.text: 7.4.3.1 The inverse of a 3x3 matrix - Gauss elimination method

questiontext.text:
The inverse of a \(3\times 3\) matrix â€“ Gauss elimination method Den inverse av en \(3\times 3\) matrise - Gauss eliminasjonsmetode.

It is true, in general, that if the determinant of a matrix is zero then that matrix has no inverse. If the determinant is non-zero then the matrix has a (unique) inverse. In this Section and the next we look at two ways of finding the inverse of a \(3\times 3\) matrix; larger matrices can be inverted by the same methods - the process is more tedious and takes longer. The \(2\times 2\) case could be handled similarly but as we have seen we have a simple formula to use. Generelt er det sant at hvis determinanten til en matrise er null, så har ikke matrisen en invers. Hvis determinanten er forskjellig fra null, så har matrisen en (unik) invers. I denne seksjonen og den neste ser vi på to måter å finne inversen til en \(3\times 3\) matrise; større matriser kan også inverteres ved de samme metodene - prosessen er mer kjedelig og tar lengre tid. \(2\times 2\) tilfellet kan løses på en lignende måte, men som vi har sett har vi en enkel formel å bruke.

The method we now describe for finding the inverse of a matrix has many similarities to a technique used to obtain solutions of simultaneous equations. This method involves operating on the rows of a matrix in order to reduce it to a unit matrix. Metoden vi nå beskriver for å finne inversen av en matrise har mange likheter med en teknikk brukt for å finne løsninger av samtidige ligninger. Denne metoden innebærer å operere på radene i en matrise for å redusere den til en enhetsmatrise.

The row operations we shall use are De radoperasjonene vi skal bruke er

  1. interchanging two rows å bytte om på to rader

  2. multiplying a row by a constant factor multiplisere en rad med en konstant faktor

  3. adding a multiple of one row to another. å legge til en multiplikasjon av en rad til en annen.

Note that in (ii) and (iii) the multiple could be negative or fractional, or both.  Merk at i både (ii) og (iii) kan multiplikatoren være negativ eller brøk, eller begge deler.

The Gauss elimination method is outlined in the following Key Point: Gauss eliminasjonsmetode er beskrevet i følgende nøkkelpunkt:

Key Point Nøkkelpunkt

Matrix Inverse - Gauss Elimination Method Invers til et Matrise - Gauss Eliminasjonsmetode

We use the result, quoted without proof, that: Vi bruker resultatet, sitert uten bevis, at:

if a sequence of row operations applied to a square matrix \(A\) reduces hvis en rekke radoperasjoner brukt på en kvadratisk matrise \(A\) reduserer den til

it to the identity matrix \(I\) of the same size then the same sequence of hvis den blir multiplisert med identitetsmatrisen \(I\) av samme størrelse, vil den samme sekvensen av

operations applied to \(I\) reduces it to \(A^{-1}\).
 Operasjoner som blir brukt på \(I\) reduserer det til \(A^{-1}\).

Three points to note: Tre punkter å merke seg:

  • If it is impossible to reduce \(A\) to \(I\) then \(A^{-1}\) does not exist. This will become evident by the appearance of a row of zeros.Hvis det er umulig å redusere \(A\) til \(I\) så eksisterer ikke \(A^{-1}\). Dette vil bli tydelig ved utseendet til en rad med nuller.

  • There is no unique procedure for reducing \(A\) to \(I\) and it is experience which leads to selection of the optimum route. Det er ingen unik prosedyre for å redusere \(A\) til \(I\), og det er erfaring som fører til valg av den optimale ruten.

  • It is more efficient to do the two reductions, \(A\) to \(I\) and \(I\) to \(A^{-1}\), simultaneously. Det er mer effektivt å gjøre de to reduksjonene, \(A\) til \(I\) og \(I\) til \(A^{-1}\), samtidig.

Suppose we wish to find the inverse of the matrix Anta at vi ønsker å finne inversen til matrisen

\[A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 3 & 3 \\ 1 & 4 & 3 \\ 2 & 7 & 7 \end{bmatrix}\]

We first place \(A\) and \(I\) adjacent to each other. Vi plasserer først \(A\) og \(I\) ved siden av hverandre.

\[ \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 3 & 3 \\ 1 & 4 & 3 \\ 2 & 7 & 7 \end{bmatrix} \quad \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \]
Phase 1

We now proceed by changing the columns of \(A\) left to right to reduce \(A\) to the form Vi går nå videre ved å endre kolonnene i \(A\) fra venstre til høyre for å redusere \(A\) til formen

\[\begin{bmatrix} 1 & * & * \\ 0 & 1 & * \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix},\]

where \(*\) can be any number. This form is called upper triangular. hvor \(*\) kan være et hvilket som helst tall. Dette kalles øvre triangulær.

First we subtract row 1 from row 2 and twice row 1 from row 3. â€˜Rowâ€™ refers to both matrices. Først trekker vi rad 1 fra rad 2 og to ganger rad 1 fra rad 3. 'Rad' refererer til begge matrisene.

\[ \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 3 & 3 \\ 1 & 4 & 3 \\ 2 & 7 & 7 \end{bmatrix} \quad \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \quad \xrightarrow[R3 - 2R1]{R2 - R1} \quad \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 3 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \quad \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ -1 & 1 & 0 \\ -2 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \]

Now we subtract row 2 from row 3. Nå trekker vi rad 2 fra rad 3.

\[ \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 3 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \quad \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ -1 & 1 & 0 \\ -2 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \quad \xrightarrow{R3 - R2} \quad \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 3 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \quad \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ -1 & 1 & 0 \\ -1 & -1 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \]
Phase 2

This consists of continuing the row operations to reduce the elements above the leading diagonal to zero. Dette består i å fortsette radoperasjonene for å redusere elementene over den ledende diagonale til null.

We proceed right to left. We subtract 3 times row 3 from row 1 (the elements in row 2 column 3 is already zero). Vi går fra høyre mot venstre. Vi trekker fra 3 ganger rad 3 fra rad 1 (elementene i rad 2 kolonne 3 er allerede null).

\[ \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 3 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \quad \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ -1 & 1 & 0 \\ -1 & -1 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \quad \xrightarrow{R1 - 3R3} \quad \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 3 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \quad \begin{bmatrix} 4 & 3 & -3 \\ -1 & 1 & 0 \\ -1 & -1 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \]

Finally we subtract 3 times row 2 from row 1. Til slutt trekker vi fra 3 ganger rad 2 fra rad 1.

\[ \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 3 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \quad \begin{bmatrix} 4 & 3 & -3 \\ -1 & 1 & 0 \\ -1 & -1 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \quad \xrightarrow{R1 - 3R2} \quad \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \quad \begin{bmatrix} 7 & 0 & -3 \\ -1 & 1 & 0 \\ -1 & -1 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \]

Then we have Da har vi

\[A^{-1} = \begin{bmatrix} 7 & 0 & -3 \\ -1 & 1 & 0 \\ -1 & -1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\]

(This can be verified by showing that \(AA^{-1} - I\) or \(A^{-1}A = I\).) (Dette kan verifiseres ved å vise at \(AA^{-1} - I\) eller \(A^{-1}A = I\).)

name.text: 7.4.4.1 The inverse of a 3x3 matrix ─ determinant method

questiontext.text:
The inverse of a \(3\times 3\) matrix - determinant method Den inversen av en \(3\times 3\) matrise - determinanten metode

This method which employs determinants, is of importance from a theoretical perspective. The numerical computations involved are too heavy for matrices of higher order than \(3\times 3\) and in such cases the Gauss elimination approach is preferred.  Denne metoden, som bruker determinanter, er av betydning fra et teoretisk perspektiv. De numeriske beregningene som er involvert, er for tunge for matriser med høyere orden enn \(3\times 3\), og i slike tilfeller foretrekkes Gauss-elimineringsmetoden.

To obtain \(A^{-1}\) using the determinant approach the steps in the following keypoint are followed: For å få \(A^{-1}\) ved å bruke determinanttilnærmingen, følges trinnene i følgende nøkkelpunkt:

Key Point
 Nøkkelpunkt

Matrix Inverse - the Determinant Method

Given a square matrix \(A\), we first calculate \(|A|\). If \(|A|=0\) then \(A^{-1}\) does not exist.  Gitt en matrise \(A\), beregner vi først \(|A|\). Hvis \(|A|=0\), eksisterer ikke \(A^{-1}\).

If \(|A|\neq 0\) we can proceed to find the inverse matrix, as follows: Hvis \(|A|\neq 0\) kan vi fortsette med å finne den inverse matrisen på følgende måte:

  • Replace each element of \(A\) by its cofactor
  • Transpose the result to form the adjoint matrix, denoted by \(\mathrm{adj}(A)\)
  • Then calculate \(A^{-1}=\frac{1}{|A|}\mathrm{adj}(A)\).

name.text: 7.4.2.2 The inverse of a 2 x 2 matrix

questiontext.text: Which of the following matrices has an inverse?

feedback.text: \(|C|=2-2 =0\). Therefore \(C\) has no inverse because its determinant is zero.

questiontext.text:
Exercise Oppgave

Consider \(A={@A@}\), and let \(B={@B@}\) be a possible inverse of \(A\). La \(A={@A@}\) være gitt, og la \(B={@B@}\) være en mulig invers av \(A\).

  1. Find \(AB\) and \(BA\) Finn \(AB\) og \(BA\)

    \(AB= \) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

    \(BA= \) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]][[feedback:prt2]]

  2. Equate the elements of \(AB\) to those of \(I={@I@}\) and try to solve the resulting four equations. Sammenligne elementene til \(AB\) til elementene for \(I={@I@}\) og prøve da å løse de fire likninger som følger.

    What does your solution tell you about finding an inverse of \(A\)? Hva kan du si om inversen til \(A\) mht. løsnigen din?

generalfeedback.text:
1. For \(A={@A@}\), \(B={@B@}\) the products are

    \[AB={@ta1@}, BA={@ta2@}.\]

Equating \(AB=I\) yields

\[a=1, b=0, a=0, b=1/2.\]

This is a contradiction, and hence the matrix \(A\) has no inverse and is said to be a singular matrix.

A matrix with an inverse is said to be non-singular.

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

questiontext.text:
Exercise Øvelse

Form the matrix products \(AB\) and \(BA\) where Lage matriseproduktene \(AB\) og \(BA\) hvor

\(A={@A@}\) and \(B={@B@}\).

\(AB=\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]

\(BA=\) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]] [[feedback:prt2]]

generalfeedback.text:
For \(A={@A@}\), \(B={@B@}\) the products are: \[AB={@ta1@}, \quad BA={@ta2@}\]

For \(A={@A@}\), \(B={@B@}\) er produktene: \[AB={@ta1@}, \quad BA={@ta2@}\]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

name.text: 7.4.2.3 Which 2 x 2 matrix has an inverse?

questiontext.text:
Exercise Øvelse

Which of the following matrices are invertible? Find the inverse where possible. Hvilken av de følgende matriser er inverterbart? Finn inversen der det er mulig.

  1. \(A = {@A@}\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]

  2. \(B = {@B@}\) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]] [[feedback:prt2]]

  3. \(C = {@C@}\) [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]] [[feedback:prt3]]

  4. \(D = {@D@}\) [[input:ans4]] [[validation:ans4]] [[feedback:prt4]]

  5. \(E = {@E@}\) [[input:ans5]] [[validation:ans5]] [[feedback:prt5]]

generalfeedback.text:
Recall that a \(2 \times 2\) has an inverse if and only if its determinant is nonzero.

  1. The determinant of \(A = {@A@}\) is \(\lvert A \rvert = {@detWithSteps(A)@} = {@ev(detWithSteps(A),simp)@} \neq 0\). Therefore, \(A\) is invertible.

  2. The determinant of \(B = {@B@}\) is \(\lvert B \rvert = {@detWithSteps(B)@} = {@ev(detWithSteps(B),simp)@} \neq 0\). Therefore, \(B\) is invertible.

  3. The determinant of \(C = {@C@}\) is \(\lvert C \rvert = {@detWithSteps(C)@} = {@ev(detWithSteps(C),simp)@}\). Therefore, \(C\) is not invertible.

  4. The determinant of \(D = {@D@}\) is \(\lvert D \rvert = {@detWithSteps(D)@} = {@ev(detWithSteps(D),simp)@} \neq 0\). Therefore, \(D\) is invertible.

  5. The determinant of \(E = {@E@}\) is \(\lvert E \rvert = {@detWithSteps(E)@} = {@ev(detWithSteps(E),simp)@}\). Therefore, \(E\) is not invertible.

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

questiontext.text:
Exercise Øvelse

Find the inverses of the following matrices Finn inversene til de følgende matriser

\(A={@A@}\), \(B={@B@}\), \(C={@C@}\).

  1. \(A^{-1}=\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]
  2. \(B^{-1}=\) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]] [[feedback:prt2]]
  3. \(C^{-1}=\) [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]] [[feedback:prt3]]

generalfeedback.text:
Recall that the inverse of a \(2 \times 2\) matrix \(A = {@matrixabcd@}\) is given by the formula Husk at inversen til en \(2 \times 2\) matrix \(A = {@matrixabcd@}\) er gitt av formelen

\[A^{-1} = \frac{1}{ad - bc} {@matrixdbca@}.\]

We apply this to each of the given matrices. Vi anvender dette til hvert av de gitte matriser.

  1. For \(A = {@A@}\), we have For \(A = {@A@}\), vi har

    \[A^{-1} = \frac{1}{{@determinant(A)@}} {@preInv(A)@} = {@ta1@}.\]

  2. For \(B = {@B@}\), we have For \(B = {@B@}\), vi har

    \[B^{-1} = \frac{1}{{@determinant(B)@}} {@preInv(B)@} = {@ta2@}.\]

  3. For \(C = {@C@}\), we have For \(C = {@C@}\), vi har

    \[C^{-1} = \frac{1}{{@determinant(C)@}} {@preInv(C)@} = {@ta3@}.\]

truefeedback.text: It appears you have given the matrix \(-A\)! This is not the inverse matrix. Recall the inverse of a 2 \(\times\) 2 matrix \[{@matrixabcd@}\] is \[\frac{1}{ad-bc}{@matrixdbca@}.\] Please try part (a) again!

It appears you have given the matrix \(-B\)! This is not the inverse matrix. Recall the inverse of a 2 \(\times\) 2 matrix \[{@matrixabcd@}\] is \[\frac{1}{ad-bc}{@matrixdbca@}.\] Please try part (b) again!

It appears you have given the matrix \(-C\)! This is not the inverse matrix. Recall the inverse of a 2 \(\times\) 2 matrix \[{@matrixabcd@}\] is \[\frac{1}{ad-bc}{@matrixdbca@}.\] Please try part (c) again!

questiontext.text:
Exercise Øvelse

It can be shown that the matrix \({A}={@A@}\) represents a clockwise rotation through an angle \(\theta\) in an \(xy\)-plane about the origin. The matrix \(B\) represents a rotation anti-clockwise through an angle \(\theta\). It is therefore given by
 Matrisen \({A}={@A@}\) representerer et rotasjon som går med klokken gjennom en vinkel \(\theta\) i et \(xy\)-plan om origo. Matrisen\(B\) representerer et rotasjon mot klokken gjennom et vinkel \(\theta\). Det er derfor gitt av

\(B={@B1@}={@B@}\)

Form the products \(AB\) and \(BA\) for these 'rotation matrices'.
 Lage produktene \(AB\) og \(BA\) for de 'rotasjonsmatriser'.

\(AB=\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

\(BA=\) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]][[feedback:prt2]]

generalfeedback.text:
\[{AB} ={@AB@}={@I@}\]
\[{BA} ={@BA@}={@I@}\]

Effectively: a rotation through an angle \(\theta\) followed by a rotation through angle \(-\theta\) is equivalent to zero rotation. Effektivt: en rotasjon gjennom en vinkel \(\theta\) etterfulgt av en rotasjon gjennom vinkel \(-\theta\) tilsvarer nullrotasjon.

truefeedback.text: You should ensure to simplify answers using trigonometric identities.
You should ensure to simplify answers using trigonometric identities.

name.text: 7.4.3.2 Inverse of 3 x 3 matrix ─ Gauss elimination method

questiontext.text:
Exercise Øvelse

Use the Gauss elimination method to find the inverse of the following matrices Bruk Gauss eliminasjonsmetoden for å finne inversen av følgende matriser.

\[A = {@A@},\] \[B = {@B@}.\] \[A = {@A@},\] \[B = {@B@}.\]

  1. \(A^{-1}=\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]
  2. \(B^{-1}=\) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]] [[feedback:prt2]]

generalfeedback.text:
We can find the inverse of matrix \(A\) using the Gaussian elimination method. Vi kan finne inversen av matrisen \(A\) ved å bruke Gauss-eleminasjonsmetoden.

We do this by reducing the matrix \(A\) to the identity matrix \(I\). There is no unique procedure for this but here is one example. Vi gjør dette ved å redusere matrisen \(A\) til identitetsmatrisen \(I\). Det finnes ingen unik fremgangsmåte for dette, men her er et eksempel.

We first place \(A\) and \(I\) adjacent to each other. Vi plasserer først \(A\) og \(I\) ved siden av hverandre.

{@A@} {@I@}. {@A@} {@I@}.

We now proceed by changing the columns of \(A\) left to right to reduce \(A\) to the form {@upper@}, where \(n\) can be any number. This form is called upper triangular. Vi går nå videre ved å endre kolonnene i \(A\) fra venstre mot høyre for å redusere \(A\) til formen {@upper@}, hvor \(n\) kan være et vilkårlig tall. Denne formen kalles øvre triangulær.

First we swap row 1 and row 2. Først bytter vi rad 1 og rad 2.

\[{@A@} {@I@} R1 \leftrightarrow R2 \longrightarrow {@matrixa@} {@I2@} \]. \[{@A@} {@I@} R1 \leftrightarrow R2 \longrightarrow {@matrisea@} {@I2@} \].

Now we subtract {@a[2,1]@} times row 1 from row 2 and {@a[3,1]@} times row 1 from row 3. Nå trekker vi fra rad 1 multiplisert med {@a[2,1]@} fra rad 2 og {@a[3,1]@} fra rad 3.

\[{@matrixa@} {@I2@} R2 - {@a[2,1]@} R1, R3 - {@a[3,1]@} R1 \longrightarrow {@matrixb@} {@I3@}\] \[{@matrixa@} {@I2@} R2 - {@a[2,1]@} R1, R3 - {@a[3,1]@} R1 \longrightarrow {@matrixb@} {@I3@}\]

Then we divide row 2 by {@b[2,2]@} and subtract {@b[3,2]@} times row 2 from row 3. Så deler vi rad 2 med {@b[2,2]@} og trekker fra {@b[3,2]@} ganger rad 2 fra rad 3.

\[{@matrixb@} {@I3@} R2/{@b[2,2]@}, R3 - {@b[3,2]@} R2 \longrightarrow {@matrixc@} {@I4@}\]. \[{@matrixb@} {@I3@} R2/{@b[2,2]@}, R3 - {@b[3,2]@} R2 \longrightarrow {@matrixc@} {@I4@}\]

Finally we divide row 3 by {@c[3,3]@}. Til slutt deler vi rad 3 med {@c[3,3]@}.

\[{@matrixc@} {@I4@} R3/{@c[3,3]@} \longrightarrow {@matrixd@} {@I5@}\]

We would usually proceed by changing the columns of \(A\) right to left to reduce \(A\) to the form {@I@}. However, for this question we already obtained zeros above the main diagonal after we swapped row 1 and row 2. Vi ville vanligvis gå frem ved å endre kolonnene til \(A\) fra høyre til venstre for å redusere \(A\) til formen {@I@}. Imidlertid har vi for dette spørsmålet allerede fått nuller over diagonalen etter at vi byttet rad 1 og rad 2.

So we have, Så vi har,

\[A^{-1} = {@I5@}.\] \[A^{-1} = {@I5@}.\]

The method can be used to determine \(B^{-1}\) similarly. Metoden kan brukes på samme måte for å bestemme \(B^{-1}\).

truefeedback.text:
It appears you have given the matrix \(\bf -A\)! This is not the inverse matrix. Please try again!
 Jeg ser at du har gitt matrisen \(\bf -A\)! Dette er ikke den inverse matrisen. Vennligst prøv igjen!

It appears you have given the matrix \(\bf -B\)! This is not the inverse matrix. Please try again!
 Det ser ut som du har gitt matrisen \(\bf -B\)! Dette er ikke den inverse matrisen. Vennligst prøv igjen!

name.text: 7.4.4.2 Inverse of a 3 x 3 matrix ─ determinant method

questiontext.text:
Exercise Oppgave

Use the determinant method to find the inverse of the following matrices Bruk determinantmetoden for å finne inversen til følgende matriser.

\[A = {@A@},\] \[B = {@B@}.\] \[A = {@A@},\] \[B = {@B@}.\]

  1. \(A^{-1} = \) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]
  2. \(B^{-1} = \) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]] [[feedback:prt2]]

generalfeedback.text:
To find the inverse of \(A = {@A@}\) using the determinant method will require four steps. For å finne inversen av \(A = {@A@}\) ved hjelp av determinantmetoden vil det kreve fire trinn.

First we find the determinant of \(A\). Først finner vi determinanten til \(A\).

\[ \det(A) = {@detA@}. \] \[ \det(A) = {@detA@}. \]

Since \(\det(A) \neq 0\) the inverse of \(A\) exists. Siden \(\det(A) \neq 0\) finnes inversen til \(A\).

Now, we replace each element of \(A\) by its cofactor. Nå erstatter vi hvert element i \(A\) med dets kofaktor.

The cofactor of \({A}_{ij}\) is the determinant of the matrix that remains when row \(i\) and column \(j\) are removed, multiplied by \((-1)^{i+j}\). So we have, Kofaktoren til \({A}_{ij}\) er determinanten til matrisen som gjenstår når rad \(i\) og kolonne \(j\) fjernes, multiplisert med \((-1)^{i+j}\). Så vi har,

{@cofactorsA@}. {@cofactorsA@}.

Then we transpose the result to obtain the adjoint matrix: Så transponerer vi resultatet for å få den tilhørende adjungerende matrisen:

\(\mathrm{adj}(A) = {@cofactorsA@}^{T} = {@adjA@}\). \(\mathrm{adj}(A) = {@cofactorsA@}^{T} = {@adjA@}\)

Finally we obtain \(A^{-1}\) using the following formula: Til slutt får vi \(A^{-1}\) ved å bruke følgende formel:

\(A^{-1} = \frac{1}{\det(A)} \mathrm{adj}(A) = \frac{1}{@detA@} {@adjA@} = {@ta1@}\). \(A^{-1} = \frac{1}{\det(A)} \mathrm{adj}(A) = \frac{1}{@detA@} {@adjA@} = {@ta1@}\).

The method can be used to determine \(B^{-1}\) similarly, which gives \( B^{-1} = {@ta2@}.\) Metoden kan brukes på samme måte for å bestemme \(B^{-1}\), som gir \(B^{-1} = {@ta2@}.\)

truefeedback.text:
It appears you have given the matrix \(\bf -A\)! This is not the inverse matrix. Please try again!
 Beklager, jeg mente å si at jeg ga deg matrisen \(\bf A\), men ikke den inverse matrisen. La meg prøve igjen:

It appears you have given the matrix \(\bf -B\)! This is not the inverse matrix. Please try again!
 Det virker som om du har gitt matrisen \(\bf -B\)! Dette er ikke den inverse matrisen. Vennligst prøv igjen!

name.text: 7.4.5.1 Exercise: Inverse of a 2 x 2 matrix (NOT IN QUIZ)

questiontext.text:
Exercise

Find the inverses of the following matrices

\(\bf A={@A@}\), \(\bf B={@B@}\), \(\bf C={@C@}\).

  1. \(\bf A^{-1}=\) [[input:ans1]][[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]
  2. \(\bf B^{-1}=\) [[input:ans2]][[validation:ans2]] [[feedback:prt2]]
  3. \(\bf C^{-1}=\) [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]] [[feedback:prt3]]

generalfeedback.text:
FEEDBACK

The inverse of a 2 \(\times\) 2 matrix \[{@matrixabcd@}\] is \[\frac{1}{ad-bc}{@matrixdbca@}.\]

Therefore the inverse of matrix \[\bf A = {@A@}\] is

\[\bf A^{-1} = \frac{1}{({@A[1,1]@}).({@A[2,2]@}) -({@A[1,2]@}).({@A[2,1]@})}{@ta1@} = \frac{1}{({@A[1,1]*A[2,2]@}) -({@A[1,2]*A[2,1]@})}{@ta1@} ={@ta1@}.\]


The inverse of matrices \( \bf B\) and \( \bf C\) can be found similarly and are

\[ B^{-1} = {@ta2@} \quad C^{-1} = {@ta3@}.\]

truefeedback.text: It appears you have given the matrix \(\bf -A\)! This is not the inverse matrix. Recall the inverse of a 2 \(\times\) 2 matrix \[{@matrixabcd@}\] is \[\frac{1}{ad-bc}{@matrixdbca@}.\] Please try part (a) again!

It appears you have given the matrix \(\bf -B\)! This is not the inverse matrix. Recall the inverse of a 2 \(\times\) 2 matrix \[{@matrixabcd@}\] is \[\frac{1}{ad-bc}{@matrixdbca@}.\] Please try part (b) again!

It appears you have given the matrix \(\bf -C\)! This is not the inverse matrix. Recall the inverse of a 2 \(\times\) 2 matrix \[{@matrixabcd@}\] is \[\frac{1}{ad-bc}{@matrixdbca@}.\] Please try part (c) again!

name.text: 7.4.5.2 (not in quiz): Gauss elimination method ─ inverse of 3 x 3 matrix

questiontext.text:
Use the Gauss elimination method to find the inverse of the following matrices

\[\bf A = {@A@},\] \[\bf B = {@B@}.\]

(a) \(\bf A^{-1}=\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]


(b) \(\bf B^{-1}=\) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]][[feedback:prt2]]

generalfeedback.text:
FEEDBACK

We can find the inverse of matrix \(\bf A\) using the Gaussian elimination method.

We do this by reducing the matrix \(\bf A\) to the identity matrix \(\bf I\). There is no unique procedure for this but here is one example.

We first place \(\bf A\) and \(\bf I\) adjacent to each other.

{@A@} {@I@}.

We now proceed by changing the columns of \(\bf A\) left to right to reduce \(\bf A\) to the form {@upper@},

where \(n\) can be any number. This form is called upper triangular.

First we swap row 1 and row 2.

\[{@A@} {@I@} R1 \leftrightarrow R2 \longrightarrow {@matrixa@} {@I2@}. \]

Now we subtract {@a[2,1]@} times row 1 from row 2 and {@a[3,1]@} times row 1 from row 3.

\[{@matrixa@} {@I2@} R2 - {@a[2,1]@} R1, R3 - {@a[3,1]@} R1 \longrightarrow {@matrixb@} {@I3@}.\]

Then we divide row 2 by {@b[2,2]@} and subtract {@b[3,2]@} times row 2 from row 3.

\[{@matrixb@} {@I3@} R2/{@b[2,2]@}, R3 - {@b[3,2]@} R2 \longrightarrow {@matrixc@} {@I4@}.\]

Finally we divide row 3 by {@c[3,3]@}.

\[{@matrixc@} {@I4@} R3/{@c[3,3]@} \longrightarrow {@matrixd@} {@I5@}.\]

We would usually proceed by changing the columns of \(\bf A\) right to left to reduce \(\bf A\) to the form {@I@}. However, for this question we already obtained zeros above the main diagonal after we swapped row 1 and row 2.

So we have,

\[\bf A^{-1} = {@I5@}.\]


The method can be used to determine \(\bf B^{-1}\) similarly, which gives \( B^{-1} = {@ta2@}.\)

truefeedback.text: It appears you have given the matrix \(\bf -A\)! This is not the inverse matrix. Please try again!
It appears you have given the matrix \(\bf -B\)! This is not the inverse matrix. Please try again!

name.text: 7.4.5.3 (not in quiz): Determinant method ─ Inverse of a 3 x 3 matrix

questiontext.text:
Use the determinant method to find the inverse of the following matrices

\[\bf A = {@A@},\] \[\bf B = {@B@}.\]

(a) \(\bf A^{-1}=\) [[input:ans1]].

[[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]

(b) \(\bf B^{-1}=\) [[input:ans2]].

[[validation:ans2]] [[feedback:prt2]]

generalfeedback.text:
FEEDBACK

To find the inverse of \(\bf A = {@A@}\) using the determinant method will require four steps.

First we find the determinant of \(\bf A.\)

\[ \det(\bf A) = {@detA@} .\]

Since \(\det(\bf A) \neq 0\) the inverse of \(\bf A\) exists.

Now, we replace each element of \(\bf A\) by its cofactor.

The cofactor of \({\bf A}_{ij}\) is the determinant of the matrix that remains when row \(i\) and column \(j\) are removed, multiplied by \((-1)^{i+j}\). So we have,

{@cofactorsA@}.

Then we transpose the result to obtain the adjoint matrix:

\(\bf adj(A) = {@cofactorsA@}^{T} = {@adjA@}.\)

Finally we obtain \(\bf A^{-1}\) using the following formula:

\(\bf A^{-1} = \frac{1}{\det(A)} adj(A) = \frac{1}{@detA@} {@adjA@} = {@ta1@}.\)

The method can be used to determine \(\bf B^{-1}\) similarly, which gives \(B^{-1} = {@ta2@}.\)

truefeedback.text: It appears you have given the matrix \(\bf -A\)! This is not the inverse matrix. Please try again!
It appears you have given the matrix \(\bf -B\)! This is not the inverse matrix. Please try again!
